title.narrative:
Civil society capacity to participate in the UPR process, to draw attention to structural risks of atrocities in developing countries, and to assist governments from developing countries in implementing UPR recommendations is strengthened.
Governments from targeted developing countries respond to UPR recommendations and the efforts of civil society by developing and/or improving national mechanisms for atrocity prevention.

Through workshops the Global Centre guides local CSOs in five regions on how to identify risk factors for atrocities and alert governments from developing countries to such vulnerabilities during the UPR process. Following civil society participation in the UPR, governments from particularly developing countries are given recommendations aimed at improving national mechanisms for atrocity prevention and take concrete steps towards implementing them.

target.value: The Global Centre develops workshop and training materials. The Global Centre identifies and develops relationships with local and national civil society actors engaged in the UPR process in the identified regions (three in sub-Saharan Africa, one in Asia, and one in Latin America).

The Global Centre holds five regional workshops for developing countries on the inclusion of atrocity prevention lens in the UPR. Members of civil society who have participated in Global Centre workshops begin the process of identifying risk factors for atrocity crimes in developing countries in preparation for the fourth UPR cycle (July 2022-January 2027).

title.narrative:
Monitor and analyse developing countries at risk of or currently facing mass atrocity situations to provide high-quality policy recommendations to UN member states and international institutions in order to mobilize appropriate action for atrocity prevention and human rights protection.
Clarify the implementation of R2P and the application of an atrocity prevention lens by various particular developing countries, international/ regional organizations and other relevant bodies.

The Global Centre publishes and provides clear and concrete policy guidance on how to respond to particular country situations where populations are at risk of or experiencing mass atrocity crimes. Over 60 governments and international/local civil society actors echo the Global Centre’s analysis and recommendations related to particularly developing countries, and, where relevant, implement specific policy actions to assist vulnerable populations in these countries.

target.value:
The Global Centre publishes six issues of R2P Monitor and 50 issues of Atrocity Alert, highlighting particularly developing countries where populations remain at risk of atrocities as well as newly-emerging country situations. Policy makers within relevant governments and international institutions consult Global Centre analysis when developing a response to particular developing country situations and acknowledge the utility of such analysis, particularly in rapidly-evolving situations.
The Global Centre will hold 4 events and publish two policy briefs on R2P, atrocity prevention and cross-cutting issues, including human rights, sustainable development and hate speech. Briefs are shared with the Global Centre’s network, which includes a list of more than 4,000 policy makers across the world as well as more than 300,000 social media followers. More than 100 people, including representatives of governments from developing countries and UN officials, attend each event.

title.narrative: National governments of targeted developing countries institutionalize atrocity prevention within their systems to promote human rights and achieve SDG goals. The international community systematically applies an atrocity prevention lens to situations in developing countries and responds in a timely manner to prevent and halt atrocities.

Governments in targeted developing countries accept UPR recommendations related to atrocity prevention and pledge to implement them. International institutions (including the UN Security Council, Human Rights Council, and General Assembly, as well as various regional organizations) systematically include atrocity prevention in their assessment of developing country situations and in developing appropriate response to countries where populations are at risk.

target.value: Three governments of developing countries accept UPR recommendations related to atrocity prevention and pledge to implement them. This could be a model which can then be replicated by other countries. International institutions (including the UN Security Council, Human Rights Council, and General Assembly, as well as various regional organizations) systematically include atrocity prevention in their assessment of four developing country situations and in developing appropriate responses to developing countries where populations are at risk.
